Description: openbsd
Reasoning: The issue is in the implementation of ssh protocol via the OpenSSH tool, where an additional packet sent can be exploited.
Unnamed: 2: The "echo simulation" traffic analysis countermeasure in OpenSSH before 2.9.9p2 sends an additional echo packet after the password and carriage return is entered, which could allow remote attackers to determine that the countermeasure is being used.

Description: openbsd, redhat, oracle, canonical, siemens, netapp, debian
Software: debian_linux, data_ontap_edge, scalance_x204rna_firmware, steelstore_cloud_integrated_storage, oncommand_unified_manager, service_processor, virtual_storage_console, storage_replication_adapter, sun_zfs_storage_appliance_kit, clustered_data_ontap, enterprise_linux_workstation, fas_baseboard_management_controller, data_ontap, vasa_provider, cloud_backup, cn1610, openssh, enterprise_linux_desktop, scalance_x204rna, enterprise_linux_server, cn1610_firmware, aff_baseboard_management_controller, ubuntu_linux, ontap_select_deploy
Reasoning: Bad implementation of ssh protocol in the OpenSSH tool, where there is improper handling of auth requests.
Unnamed: 2: OpenSSH through 7.7 is prone to a user enumeration vulnerability due to not delaying bailout for an invalid authenticating user until after the packet containing the request has been fully parsed, related to auth2-gss.c, auth2-hostbased.c, and auth2-pubkey.c.

Description: nokia
Reasoning: The issue is exploitation of Hardcoded credentials of SSH (thus dependency and not related to SSH) in the firmware
Unnamed: 2: The Alcatel Lucent I-240W-Q GPON ONT using firmware version 3FE54567BOZJ19 contains multiple hard coded credentials for the Telnet and SSH interfaces.

Description: ssh
Reasoning: The vulnerabillity arises due to the design of SSH handling of CBC/CFB modes and CRC-32 checksums. a logical vulnerability.
Unnamed: 2: SSH 1.2.25, 1.2.23, and other versions, when used in in CBC (Cipher Block Chaining) or CFB (Cipher Feedback 64 bits) modes, allows remote attackers to insert arbitrary data into an existing stream between an SSH client and server by using a known plaintext attack and computing a valid CRC-32 checksum for the packet, aka the "SSH insertion attack."

Description: paloaltonetworks
Reasoning: Implementation flaw in Palo alto PAN-OS due to improper validation of SSH command parameters
Unnamed: 2: The device management command line interface (CLI) in Palo Alto Networks PAN-OS before 5.0.18, 5.1.x before 5.1.11, 6.0.x before 6.0.13, 6.1.x before 6.1.10, and 7.0.x before 7.0.5H2 allows remote authenticated administrators to execute arbitrary OS commands via an SSH command parameter.

Description: dell
Reasoning: Implementation flaw in dell machines which allows to perform DOS attack using SSH connection. correct implementation would have made it not possible.
Unnamed: 2: The SSH service on Dell PowerConnect 3348 1.2.1.3, 3524p 2.0.0.48, and 5324 2.0.1.4 switches allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (device reset) or possibly execute arbitrary code by sending many packets to TCP port 22.

Description: grandstream
Software: ucm6204, ucm6208_firmware, ucm6202, ucm6208, ucm6202_firmware, ucm6204_firmware
Reasoning: Implementation flaw due to expliotation of SSH crafted command.
Unnamed: 2: Grandstream UCM6200 series firmware version 1.0.20.23 and below is vulnerable to OS command injection via SSH. An authenticated remote attacker can execute commands as the root user by issuing a specially crafted "unset" command.

Description: openbsd, redhat
Reasoning: Implementation flaw due to supply chain compromise.  Its dependent on SSH protocol as the malicious code is embedded in OpenSSH software, and the exploit relies on the SSH service being active to execute the malicious payload.
Unnamed: 2: Certain Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL) 4 and 5 packages for OpenSSH, as signed in August 2008 using a legitimate Red Hat GPG key, contain an externally introduced modification (Trojan Horse) that allows the package authors to have an unknown impact.  NOTE: since the malicious packages were not distributed from any official Red Hat sources, the scope of this issue is restricted to users who may have obtained these packages through unofficial distribution points.  As of 20080827, no unofficial distributions of this software are known.

Description: cisco
Reasoning: implementation fault which is being used by logging in with SSH. the implementation fault does not exploit the protocol by itself but it has dependency of using it.
Unnamed: 2: A vulnerability in Cisco Application Policy Infrastructure Controller (APIC) could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to gain higher privileges than the account is assigned. The attacker will be granted the privileges of the last user to log in, regardless of whether those privileges are higher or lower than what should have been granted. The attacker cannot gain root-level privileges. The vulnerability is due to a limitation with how Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) grants privileges to remotely authenticated users when login occurs via SSH directly to the local management interface of the APIC. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by authenticating to the targeted device. The attacker's privilege level will be modified to match that of the last user to log in via SSH. An exploit could allow the attacker to gain elevated privileges and perform CLI commands that should be restricted by the attacker's configured role. Cisco Bug IDs: CSCvc34335. Known Affected Releases: 1.0(1e), 1.0(1h), 1.0(1k), 1.0(1n), 1.0(2j), 1.0(2m), 1.0(3f), 1.0(3i), 1.0(3k), 1.0(3n), 1.0(4h), 1.0(4o); 1.1(0.920a), 1.1(1j), 1.1(3f); 1.2 Base, 1.2(2), 1.2(3), 1.2.2; 1.3(1), 1.3(2), 1.3(2f); 2.0 Base, 2.0(1).

Description: juniper
Reasoning: Implementation flaw due insufficient validation of SSH keys.
Unnamed: 2: Insufficient validation of SSH keys in Junos Space before 15.2R2 allows man-in-the-middle (MITM) type of attacks while a Space device is communicating with managed devices.

Description: zyxel
Reasoning: implementation flaw in software caused due hardcoded SSH key (thus dependency and not related to SSH)
Unnamed: 2: Zyxel CloudCNM SecuManager 3.1.0 and 3.1.1 has a hardcoded DSA SSH key for the root account within the /opt/axess chroot directory tree.

sf302-08_firmware, sf302-08p, sf300-24, sg350-28p_firmware, esw2-350g-52dc
Reasoning: Implementation flaw due to improper processing of SSH connections.
Unnamed: 2: A vulnerability in the Secure Shell (SSH) subsystem of Cisco Small Business Managed Switches software could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to cause a reload of the affected switch, resulting in a denial of service (DoS) condition. The vulnerability is due to improper processing of SSH connections. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by logging in to an affected switch via SSH and sending a malicious SSH message. This vulnerability affects the following Cisco products when SSH is enabled: Small Business 300 Series Managed Switches, Small Business 500 Series Stackable Managed Switches, 350 Series Managed Switches, 350X Series Stackable Managed Switches, 550X Series Stackable Managed Switches, ESW2 Series Advanced Switches. Cisco Bug IDs: CSCvb48377.

Description: ssh
Reasoning: logical vulnerability due to inherent weaknesses in SSH design for handling BER/DER packets.
Unnamed: 2: SSH Secure Shell before 3.2.9 allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service via malformed BER/DER packets.

Description: netapp, winscp, openbsd, siemens
Software: scalance_x204rna_eec_firmware, openssh, scalance_x204rna, element_software, winscp, scalance_x204rna_eec, storage_automation_store, scalance_x204rna_firmware, ontap_select_deploy
Reasoning: Implementation flaw due to improper handling of stderr output.
Unnamed: 2: In OpenSSH 7.9, due to accepting and displaying arbitrary stderr output from the server, a malicious server (or Man-in-The-Middle attacker) can manipulate the client output, for example to use ANSI control codes to hide additional files being transferred.

Description: cisco
Software: catalyst_3750g, cisco_1500_wireless_lan_controller, cisco_2100_wireless_lan_controller, cisco_4200_wireless_lan_controller, cisco_4100_wireless_lan_controller, cisco_2000_wireless_lan_controller, cisco_4400_wireless_lan_controller
Reasoning: Implementation flaw in cisco device, where the core of the problem is a memory leak. the exploitation of this issue is dependent on the use of SSH for management purposes.
Unnamed: 2: Memory leak on the Cisco Wireless LAN Controller (WLC) platform 4.x before 4.2.205.0, 5.1 before 5.1.163.0, and 5.0 and 5.2 before 5.2.178.0, as used in Cisco 1500 Series, 2000 Series, 2100 Series, 4100 Series, 4200 Series, and 4400 Series Wireless Services Modules (WiSM), WLC Modules for Integrated Services Routers, and Catalyst 3750G Integrated Wireless LAN Controllers, allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (memory consumption and device reload) via SSH management connections, aka Bug ID CSCsw40789.

Description: riorey
Reasoning: The issue is exploitation of Hardcoded credentials of SSH (thus dependency on SSH).
Unnamed: 2: RioRey RIOS 4.6.6 and 4.7.0 uses an undocumented, hard-coded username (dbadmin) and password (sq!us3r) for an SSH tunnel, which allows remote attackers to gain privileges via port 8022.

Description: selinux_project
Reasoning: Implementation flaw due to improper handling of hardlinks and SELinux policy settings, the vulnerability is dependent on SSH since it causes prevention of SSH logins.
Unnamed: 2: selinux-policy when sysctl fs.protected_hardlinks are set to 0 allows local users to cause a denial of service (SSH login prevention) by creating a hardlink to /etc/passwd from a directory named .config, and updating selinux-policy.

Description: suse, openbsd, redhat
Reasoning: Implementation flaw in OpenSSH which doesn't properly sanitize environment variables - allowing privilege escalation.
Unnamed: 2: OpenSSH 3.0.1 and earlier with UseLogin enabled does not properly cleanse critical environment variables such as LD_PRELOAD, which allows local users to gain root privileges.

Description: cdatatec
Software: fd1104sn_firmware, fd1616gs, fd1216s-r1, fd1204sn-r2_firmware, fd1104, 92408a, 92408a_firmware, 97042p, 9016a, 92416a, 97028p, 97168p_firmware, 97016, fd1108s, fd1608gs_firmware, fd1608sn, 72408a, fd8000_firmware, fd1204sn-r2, fd1002s, 9288, fd1104sn, fd1104b, 97042p_firmware, fd1204s-r2_firmware, fd1108s_firmware, 97016_firmware, fd8000, 97168p, fd1204sn_firmware, fd1616gs_firmware, fd1204s-r2, 97028p_firmware, fd1204sn, 72408a_firmware, 92416a_firmware, 97024p, 9008a, 97084p_firmware, 9008a_firmware, fd1616sn_firmware, fd1616sn, 97024p_firmware, fd1104b_firmware, fd1208s-r2, fd1002s_firmware, fd1104s, 9016a_firmware, fd1216s-r1_firmware, fd1208s-r2_firmware, fd1608gs, fd1608sn_firmware, 9288_firmware, 97084p, fd1104s_firmware, fd1104_firmware
Reasoning: Implementation flaw due to the lack of support for secured communication protocols, such as SSH.  The vulnerabilityt does not involve or exploit specific features or flaws of the SSH protocol, its just influenced by its absence.
Unnamed: 2: An issue was discovered on CDATA 72408A, 9008A, 9016A, 92408A, 92416A, 9288, 97016, 97024P, 97028P, 97042P, 97084P, 97168P, FD1002S, FD1104, FD1104B, FD1104S, FD1104SN, FD1108S, FD1204S-R2, FD1204SN, FD1204SN-R2, FD1208S-R2, FD1216S-R1, FD1608GS, FD1608SN, FD1616GS, FD1616SN, and FD8000 devices. By default, the appliance can be managed remotely only with HTTP, telnet, and SNMP. It doesn't support SSL/TLS for HTTP or SSH. An attacker can intercept passwords sent in cleartext and conduct man-in-the-middle attacks on the management of the appliance.

Description: cisco
Software: aironet_1815t_firmware, aironet_1562e, aironet_1830e_firmware, catalyst_9124axi_firmware, catalyst_9105axi, aironet_1850e_firmware, aironet_4800_firmware, 1100-8p, aironet_3800e_firmware, catalyst_9115axe_firmware, aironet_1562i_firmware, aironet_1815w_firmware, aironet_2800e, catalyst_9115axi_firmware, catalyst_9120axp, catalyst_9124axi, aironet_1850i_firmware, aironet_1562d_firmware, 1100-8p_firmware, catalyst_9115axi, catalyst_iw6300_dcw, catalyst_9124axd_firmware, 1120, catalyst_9124axd, catalyst_iw6300_dc, catalyst_9120axe, catalyst_9105axw_firmware, aironet_4800, aironet_1830e, catalyst_9130axe_firmware, aironet_2800i_firmware, catalyst_9120axe_firmware, aironet_1815i_firmware, catalyst_9800-40, catalyst_9800-l, aironet_3800i, aironet_3800p, aironet_2800e_firmware, catalyst_9120axi_firmware, catalyst_9130axi_firmware, aironet_1542i_firmware, catalyst_9117axi, aironet_1562d, aironet_3800e, catalyst_9115axe, aironet_1562e_firmware, aironet_1840i_firmware, aironet_1815m, catalyst_iw6300_ac_firmware, aironet_1815w, catalyst_9800-80, aironet_1815t, catalyst_9105axi_firmware, aironet_1850i, aironet_3800i_firmware, catalyst_9120axp_firmware, catalyst_9130axi, esw6300_firmware, catalyst_9130axe, aironet_1542i, aironet_1830i, aironet_3800p_firmware, catalyst_iw6300_dcw_firmware, catalyst_9117_firmware, catalyst_9800_firmware, 1120_firmware, aironet_1850e, aironet_2800i, 1160_integrated_services_router, aironet_1562i, aironet_1840i, aironet_1542d_firmware, catalyst_9800-cl, esw6300, catalyst_9120axi, 1160_firmware, catalyst_iw6300_dc_firmware, aironet_1830i_firmware, wireless_lan_controller_software, catalyst_9105axw, aironet_1815m_firmware, aironet_1542d, aironet_1815i, catalyst_iw6300_ac
Reasoning: Implementation flaw due to improper checking of file operations on the SSH management interface, allowing users to perform unauthorized modifications.
Unnamed: 2: A vulnerability in the SSH management feature of multiple Cisco Access Points (APs) platforms could allow a local, authenticated user to modify files on the affected device and possibly gain escalated privileges. The vulnerability is due to improper checking on file operations within the SSH management interface. A network administrator user could exploit this vulnerability by accessing an affected device through SSH management to make a configuration change. A successful exploit could allow the attacker to gain privileges equivalent to the root user.

Description: cisco
Reasoning: Implementation flaw due to improper handling of crafted SSH packets.
Unnamed: 2: The Management Interface on Cisco Content Services Switch (CSS) 11500 devices 8.20.4.02 and earlier allows remote attackers to bypass intended restrictions on local-network device access via crafted SSH packets, aka Bug ID CSCut14855.

Description: Grandstream UCM6200 series firmware version 1.0.20.23 and below is vulnerable to OS command injection via SSH. An authenticated remote attacker can execute commands as the root user by issuing a specially crafted "unset" command.
Software: ucm6204, ucm6208_firmware, ucm6202, ucm6208, ucm6202_firmware, ucm6204_firmware
Reasoning: The vulnerability is specifically related to how the SSH protocol is implemented in the Grandstream UCM6200 firmware, allowing command injection.

Description: The default SSH configuration in Rapid7 Nexpose hardware appliances shipped before June 2017 does not specify desired algorithms for key exchange and other important functions. As a result, it falls back to allowing ALL algorithms supported by the relevant version of OpenSSH and makes the installations vulnerable to a range of MITM, downgrade, and decryption attacks.
Reasoning: The vulnerability involves a misconfiguration in SSH that leads to the use of insecure algorithms, allowing MITM, downgrade, and decryption attacks. This is an implementation issue.

Description: SSH Tectia Client and Server before 6.4.19 on Windows allow local privilege escalation in nonstandard conditions. ConnectSecure on Windows is affected.
Reasoning: The vulnerability involves SSH Tectia software on Windows, allowing local privilege escalation. This is an implementation issue specific to how SSH Tectia is configured or coded.

Description: OpsRamp Gateway before 7.0.0 has a backdoor account vadmin with the password 9vt@f3Vt that allows root SSH access to the server. This issue has been resolved in OpsRamp Gateway firmware version 7.0.0 where an administrator and a system user accounts are the only available user accounts for the gateway appliance.
Reasoning: The vulnerability involves a backdoor account with a hardcoded password that allows root SSH access, making it an implementation issue.

Description: The (1) publickey_make_dss, (2) publickey_make_rsa, (3) signature_from_string, (4) ssh_do_sign, and (5) ssh_sign_session_id functions in keys.c in libssh before 0.5.3 free "an invalid pointer on an error path," which might allow remote attackers to cause a denial of service (crash) via unspecified vectors.
Reasoning: The vulnerability involves several functions in "libssh" that handle SSH operations, where improper error handling can lead to a denial of service. This is an implementation issue.

Description: Dulwich before 0.18.5, when an SSH subprocess is used, allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary commands via an ssh URL with an initial dash character in the hostname, a related issue to CVE-2017-9800, CVE-2017-12836, CVE-2017-12976, CVE-2017-1000116, and CVE-2017-1000117.
Reasoning: The vulnerability involves an SSH subprocess and how it handles specific ssh URLs, leading to arbitrary command execution. This is an implementation issue.

Description: The device management command line interface (CLI) in Palo Alto Networks PAN-OS before 5.0.18, 5.1.x before 5.1.11, 6.0.x before 6.0.13, 6.1.x before 6.1.10, and 7.0.x before 7.0.5H2 allows remote authenticated administrators to execute arbitrary OS commands via an SSH command parameter.
Reasoning: The vulnerability is related to SSH since it involves the misuse of an SSH command parameter in the CLI, (making it an implementation error), allowing authenticated administrators to execute arbitrary OS commands.

Description: A vulnerability in Cisco Application Policy Infrastructure Controller (APIC) could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to gain higher privileges than the account is assigned. The attacker will be granted the privileges of the last user to log in, regardless of whether those privileges are higher or lower than what should have been granted. The attacker cannot gain root-level privileges. The vulnerability is due to a limitation with how Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) grants privileges to remotely authenticated users when login occurs via SSH directly to the local management interface of the APIC. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by authenticating to the targeted device. The attacker's privilege level will be modified to match that of the last user to log in via SSH. An exploit could allow the attacker to gain elevated privileges and perform CLI commands that should be restricted by the attacker's configured role. Cisco Bug IDs: CSCvc34335. Known Affected Releases: 1.0(1e), 1.0(1h), 1.0(1k), 1.0(1n), 1.0(2j), 1.0(2m), 1.0(3f), 1.0(3i), 1.0(3k), 1.0(3n), 1.0(4h), 1.0(4o); 1.1(0.920a), 1.1(1j), 1.1(3f); 1.2 Base, 1.2(2), 1.2(3), 1.2.2; 1.3(1), 1.3(2), 1.3(2f); 2.0 Base, 2.0(1).
Reasoning: The vulnerability involves improper handling of privileges by the RBAC system when users authenticate via SSH, leading to privilege escalation. This is an implementation issue specific to SSH since the privilege escalation occurs due to how RBAC processes logins via SSH.

Description: The SSH service on Dell PowerConnect 3348 1.2.1.3, 3524p 2.0.0.48, and 5324 2.0.1.4 switches allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (device reset) or possibly execute arbitrary code by sending many packets to TCP port 22.
Reasoning: The vulnerability involves the SSH service and allows for denial of service or potential arbitrary code execution through exploitation of the SSH service on specific Dell switches.

Description: OpenSSH 5.6 and earlier, when J-PAKE is enabled, does not properly validate the public parameters in the J-PAKE protocol, which allows remote attackers to bypass the need for knowledge of the shared secret, and successfully authenticate, by sending crafted values in each round of the protocol, a related issue to CVE-2010-4252.
Reasoning: The vulnerability involves improper validation of public parameters in the J-PAKE protocol within OpenSSH, leading to potential unauthorized access. This is an implementation issue specific to SSH.

Description: Grandstream UCM6200 series firmware version 1.0.20.23 and below is vulnerable to OS command injection via SSH. An authenticated remote attacker can execute commands as the root user by issuing a specially crafted "unset" command.
Software: ucm6204, ucm6208_firmware, ucm6202, ucm6208, ucm6202_firmware, ucm6204_firmware
Reasoning: The vulnerability involves the execution of OS commands via a specially crafted 'unset' command through SSH.

Description: Integer overflow in sshd in OpenSSH 2.9.9 through 3.3 allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code during challenge response authentication (ChallengeResponseAuthentication) when OpenSSH is using SKEY or BSD_AUTH authentication.
Reasoning: The vulnerability involves an integer overflow in sshd that allows arbitrary code execution during challenge response authentication.

Description: eQ-3 HomeMatic CCU3 firmware 3.41.11 allows session fixation. An attacker can create session IDs and send them to the victim. After the victim logs in to the session, the attacker can use that session. The attacker could create SSH logins after a valid session and easily compromise the system.
Reasoning: The vulnerability involves session fixation, allowing attackers to take over sessions and create SSH logins to compromise the system.

Description: A vulnerability in the Secure Shell (SSH) authentication process of Cisco Small Business Switches software could allow an attacker to bypass client-side certificate authentication and revert to password authentication. The vulnerability exists because OpenSSH mishandles the authentication process. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by attempting to connect to the device via SSH. A successful exploit could allow the attacker to access the configuration as an administrative user if the default credentials are not changed. There are no workarounds available; however, if client-side certificate authentication is enabled, disable it and use strong password authentication. Client-side certificate authentication is disabled by default.

Reasoning: The vulnerability involves mishandling the SSH authentication process, allowing an attacker to bypass client-side certificate authentication.

Description: RioRey RIOS 4.6.6 and 4.7.0 uses an undocumented, hard-coded username (dbadmin) and password (sq!us3r) for an SSH tunnel, which allows remote attackers to gain privileges via port 8022.
Reasoning: The vulnerability involves the use of undocumented, hard-coded credentials for an SSH tunnel, allowing attackers to gain privileges.

Description: The Management Interface on Cisco Content Services Switch (CSS) 11500 devices 8.20.4.02 and earlier allows remote attackers to bypass intended restrictions on local-network device access via crafted SSH packets, aka Bug ID CSCut14855.
Reasoning: The vulnerability involves the use of crafted SSH packets to bypass access restrictions on the Cisco Content Services Switch

Description: Memory leak on the Cisco Wireless LAN Controller (WLC) platform 4.x before 4.2.205.0, 5.1 before 5.1.163.0, and 5.0 and 5.2 before 5.2.178.0, as used in Cisco 1500 Series, 2000 Series, 2100 Series, 4100 Series, 4200 Series, and 4400 Series Wireless Services Modules (WiSM), WLC Modules for Integrated Services Routers, and Catalyst 3750G Integrated Wireless LAN Controllers, allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (memory consumption and device reload) via SSH management connections, aka Bug ID CSCsw40789.
Software: catalyst_3750g, cisco_1500_wireless_lan_controller, cisco_2100_wireless_lan_controller, cisco_4200_wireless_lan_controller, cisco_4100_wireless_lan_controller, cisco_2000_wireless_lan_controller, cisco_4400_wireless_lan_controller
Reasoning: The vulnerability involves a memory leak triggered by SSH management connections, allowing remote attackers to cause a denial of service.

Description: A vulnerability in the Secure Shell (SSH) subsystem of Cisco Small Business Managed Switches software could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to cause a reload of the affected switch, resulting in a denial of service (DoS) condition. The vulnerability is due to improper processing of SSH connections. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by logging in to an affected switch via SSH and sending a malicious SSH message. This vulnerability affects the following Cisco products when SSH is enabled: Small Business 300 Series Managed Switches, Small Business 500 Series Stackable Managed Switches, 350 Series Managed Switches, 350X Series Stackable Managed Switches, 550X Series Stackable Managed Switches, ESW2 Series Advanced Switches. Cisco Bug IDs: CSCvb48377.

Reasoning: The vulnerability involves improper processing of SSH connections, allowing an attacker to cause a denial of service, the issue could be considered a logical flaw if the problem arises from the design of how SSH connections are processed

Description: The "echo simulation" traffic analysis countermeasure in OpenSSH before 2.9.9p2 sends an additional echo packet after the password and carriage return is entered, which could allow remote attackers to determine that the countermeasure is being used.
Reasoning: The issue is a logical flaw in the design of the echo simulation countermeasure, allowing attackers to detect its usage.

Description: Buffer overflow in Ipswitch WS_FTP Server with SSH 6.1.0.0 allows remote authenticated users to cause a denial of service (crash) and possibly execute arbitrary code via a long opendir command.
Reasoning: The vulnerability involves a buffer overflow due to improper handling of the opendir command in Ipswitch WS_FTP Server with SSH, allowing authenticated users to cause a denial of service and possibly execute arbitrary code.

Description: SSH Secure Shell before 3.2.9 allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service via malformed BER/DER packets.
Reasoning: If the improper handling of malformed BER/DER packets is due to a design flaw in the packet processing logic, this would classify it as a logical error rather than an implementation flaw.

Description: An Information Exposure vulnerability in Juniper Networks SRC Series devices configured for NETCONF over SSH permits the negotiation of weak ciphers, which could allow a remote attacker to obtain sensitive information. A remote attacker with read and write access to network data could exploit this vulnerability to display plaintext bits from a block of ciphertext and obtain sensitive information. This issue affects all Juniper Networks SRC Series versions prior to 4.13.0-R6.
Reasoning: The vulnerability involves an implementation flaw in how Juniper Networks SRC Series devices handle weak cipher negotiation in NETCONF over SSH, allowing a remote attacker to obtain sensitive information.

Description: Insufficient validation of SSH keys in Junos Space before 15.2R2 allows man-in-the-middle (MITM) type of attacks while a Space device is communicating with managed devices.
Reasoning: The vulnerability involves an implementation flaw in Junos Space's validation of SSH keys, allowing potential man-in-the-middle attacks during communication with managed devices.
